titleStmt.title: The mock-tempest, or, The enchanted castle acted at the Theatre Royal / written by T. Duffett.
titleStmt.author: Duffett, Thomas.
Shadwell, Thomas, 1642?-1692. Tempest.
Shakespeare, William, 1564-1616. Tempest.

notesStmt.note: A burlesque of Shadwell's opera, The tempest, which was based on D'Avenant's and Dryden's adaptation of Shakespeare.
The 2nd impression. Cf. Montague Summers reprint in Shakespeare adaptations, 1922, p. xiii-xiv.
Reproduction of original in British Library.

div.p: THE MOCK-TEMPEST: OR THE Enchanted Castle. ACTED AT THE Theatre Royal.
Hic totus volo rideat libellus. Mart.
LONDON, Printed for William Cademan at the Popes-Head in the lower Walk of the New Exchange in the Strand. 1675.

div.head: THE INTRODUCTION, Spoken by Mr. Hains, and Mrs. Mackarel.
div.l: YOU are of late become so mutinous,
Y'ave forc'd a reverend Bard to quit our House.
Since y'are so soon misled to ruin us,
I'le call a Spirit forth that shall declare,
What all your tricks and secret Virtues are.
What? ho Ariel!
Here's Betty— Now rail if you dare:
Speak to'em Betty— ha! asham'd, alass poor Girl,
Whisper me!— Oh I'le tell 'em— Gentlemen! she says,
Y'are grown so wild she could not stay among ye,
And yet her tender heart is loath to wrong ye.
Spare 'em not,
Whom kindness cannot stir, but stripes may move.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: O Mr. Hains! I've often felt their Love.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Poh, felt a Pudding that has taken vent,
Their love cools faster, and as soon is spent.
Think of thy high calling Betty, now th'art here,
They gaze and wish, but cannot reach thy Sphere,
Though ev'ry one could squeeze thy Orange there.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: Why this to me, Mr. Haines (d'ee conceive me) why to me?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Ay, why this to Betty?
O Virtue, Virtue! vainly art thou sought,
If such as Betty must be counted naught:
Examine your Consciences Gentlemen!
When urg'd with heat of love, and hotter Wine,
How have you begg'd, to gain your lewd design:
Betty, dear, dear, dear Betty,
I'le spend five Guinnyes on thee, if thou'lst go:
And then they shake their (d'ee concieve me) Betty is't not so, their yellow Boyes.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: Fie Mr. Hains, y'are very rude (d'ee concieve me.)

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Then speak your self.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: Gentlemen! you know what I know.
If y'are severe, all shall out by this light:
But if you will be kind, I'le still be right▪

sp.speaker: Ha
sp.l: So that's well— make thy Cursy Betty.
Now go in Child, I have something to say to these Gentlemen in private. Exit Betty.

div.head: PROLOGUE. Spoken by Mr. Hains.
div.l: SInce Heroes Ghosts, and Gods have felt your spight:
Your She Familiars, and your dear delight;
The Devils shall try their power, w'ee to night:
Some do believe that Devils ne'r have been,
Because they think, none can be worse then them:
But Female Sprights by all are felt and seen.
You see our Study is to please you all:
Lets not by stiff Tom Thimbles faction fall;
Whose censures are meer ign'rance in disguise,
The noyse of envious fools, that would seem wise.
If Bacons Brazen-head cry— that won't pass,
Strayt all the little Fops are turn'd to brass,
And Eccho to the braying of that Ass:
Although we take their shapes and sensless sounds,
Lets not be worryd by our own dull Hounds:
Let not their noyse that got your Money there,
Deprave your Iudgments, and your pleasure here.
Ye men of Sense and Wit, resume your Raign.
Th'are honour'd who by noble Foes are slain;
Such comforts wounded Lovers have who swear,
When their tormenting pains are most severe,
Dam'ee!
It does not vex me to be Clapp'd by her:
Gad she was handsome, though the sport is dear.
But who in your sight at their mercy lyes,
Much like an Eastern Malefactor dyes,
Expos'd i'th' Sun to be devour'd by flyes.
Let Language, Wit and Plot, this Night be safe,
For all our business is to make you laugh.

list.label: Prospero
list.item: a Duke, Head-keeper of the Enchanted Castle.
list.label: Alonzo
Quakero
Gonzalo
Antonio
Hypolito
list.item: Infant Duke of Mantua, Innocent and ignorant
list.label: Hectorio
Miranda
Dorinda
Stephania
Beantosser
Moustrappa
Drinkallup
Ariel
A Plenipotentiary.
Wenches, Bridewell-Keepers, Spirits, Devils, Masquers, and Prisners

div.head: ERRATA.
div.p: P. 1. for breaking r. beating Doors. P. 6. 1. 〈◊〉 for o●t. r. 〈◊〉. P. 10. l. 23. for 〈◊〉 r. b●●k. P. 12. l. ult. for it r. spit. P. 32. l. 2. for gall'd r. gally'd. l. 8. for Gentleman r. Gentlewoman. P. 49. l. 23. for puts r. puffs. P. 50. l. 33. after Trapstick. add Alonz. By thy stealers and Pickers. P. 53. l. 18. for Face r. Lace.

div.head: THE New TEMPEST OR THE Enchanted Castle.
ACT I.
SCENE I.
div.stage: A great noyse heard of breaking Doors, and breaking Windowes, crying a Whore, a Whore, &c.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: WHAT a noyse they make!

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: A roaring noyse, we shall have foul weather.

sp.speaker: Drink.
sp.p: The Dogs have us in the Wind, 'twill go hard.

sp.speaker: Stepha.
sp.p: Hectorio! Hectorio!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hectorio! Hectorio! Hectorio!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Here here Mother, what cheer, what cheer.

sp.speaker: Stepha.
sp.p: Never worse, never worse, barr up the Doors, barr up the Doors: Oh! Oh! [She whistles, Wenches run on and off again.]

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Barr up the Doors, barr up the Doors.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: Let's make all fast enough, and let'm roar the Devils head off.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Beantosser, Beantosser.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Beantosser, Beantosser, Beantosser.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Why where is this damn'd deaf flunder mouth'd drab?

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Here here, a pox o' these full mouth'd Fox hounds.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: They hunt devilish hard, I'me affrai'd they'l earth us.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Give Hectorio a dram of the Bottle, the Whey-Blooded Rogue looks as if his heart were melted into his Breeches.

div.stage: [Enter Wenches arm'd with Spitts, Forks, Tongs, Chamber-Potts, &c. they pass over the stage.]

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Bear up, bear up my brave Amazons, y'ave born Ten times as many men in your times, beigh my Girles, stand fast my stout bona Roba's; run, fly, work nimbly, nimbly ye Queans, or all's lost. [Exeunt all]

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Good friend, stand to thy tackling, and play the Man: where's Mother Stephania.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Pry'thee old Goat tye up thy Clack, and move thy hands.

sp.speaker: Quak.
sp.p: Friend, friend, look thee, bridle thy unruly member— to wit, thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Work, work, my hearte of Gold.

sp.speaker: Quak.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, my Father to whom thou spakest so unadvisedly is Duke of that building which do-eth sustain my Lord Mayors Cattle, Vidicilet, his Doggs.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Fill the sweating Tub with Stones, and set it against the Door, quick, quick.
Within— The Sweating Tub, the Sweating Tub! Stones, Stones!

sp.speaker: Quak.
sp.p: He is moreover perpetual Whiffler to the Worshipful company of Pin-makers, as I my self am.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p:
Confound thy Father and thy self. [A noyse within.] What care these Roarers for the worshipful Pin-makers.?
Silence, and to work, or I'le ram thee into a Chamber-pot, and throw thee out at Window. [Exeunt all.]

div.stage: Enter Steph. Bean. Mous. and Drink.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Stir, Wenches, stir, bring out all the Jourdans full of Water.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The Jourdans, the Jourdans, &c.

div.stage: Bean. Drink. and Mous. run off several wayes crying the Iourdans.
[A great noyse within, all crying a Whore, a Whore, a Whore, &c.]

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Send a Legion of Devils down their yelling throats to pluck their lungs out.— Out ye bauling Curs, ye ill-bred hounds, here are Whores enough for you all, All, if you would behave your selves like civil Gentlemen, and come one after another.
Down, down, down to the Sellar Windows.—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The Sellar Windows, the Sellar Windows. [The Wenches run down the Trap Door.]

div.stage: Enter Bean. Mous and Drink. hastily one after another.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Undone, undone, not one drop of Water in the house.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: With hard labour all their moisture turns into sweat.

sp.speaker: Drink.
sp.p: Th'are dryer then hung Beef, and almost as black too.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Your advice, your advice Mother.

sp.speaker: Drink.
sp.p: Dispatch, or w'are ruin'd.—

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Get up in the Windows, you musty Queens, make water in their Eyes, and burn e'm out, I'me fure y'are hot enough.—

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Turn out, turn out all hands to the Back door: is this a time to prate ye spurr-gald jades, ye over-rid Hackneys.—

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: O you huffing Son of a Whore.

sp.speaker: Drink.
sp.p: You rotten Jack in a box.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: You foul mouth'd Nickumpoop.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Prate on, prate on, d'ee hear how it Thunders?— stand still and be damn'd, I'le shift well enough for one.

sp.speaker: Steph
sp.p: Turn out, turn out Seditious mutiners, ye or I'le have ye all flead— Out, out! [Exeunt Bean. Mous. and Drink.]

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.p: More noyse and terrour then a Tempest at Sea.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: The green Chamber, the green Chamber. [Stephania whistles, the Wenches come up from the Trapp-door.]

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Aloft, aloft, to the green Chamber, all to the green Chamber— Aloft, aloft.— [Exeunt Beant. and Wenches.]

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: My Honour, my Reputation.—

sp.speaker: Quak.
sp.p: Yea! Reputation, Reputation!— Woo man, ah! ha!

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Reputation! ye crop-ear'd whelps, Reputation! is not my Reputation dearer to me then your lives, and Souls? Down with the Close stool upon their heads.

You louzy farandinical Sots, Reputation! I have had Lords— Lords! thou whey-bearded Ananias, and then I had a blessing on my endeavours; but this is justly fall'n upon me, for dealing with such zealous Whore-masters, thin-gutted 3 d. Customers— Out of my sight, and to work, or by the beards of my renowned Predceestors I'le have you hung out like Wool-sacks to defend my Walls. See if thou canst preach the Rabble to Silence, thou canting Hypocritical Abednego.

sp.speaker: Quak.
sp.p: Yea, thou babylonish Whore in grain, thou Harlot of a London dye, thou shalt see the strength of the power of a um— Thou shalt see, I say, look ye Friends, Brethren and Sisters— Give heedful attention, and a, and I say a um— [A shout within, and dirt thrown in his mouth.] [Exeunt all.]

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: We are gone, we are gone, th'are all broke in the Closet Window,

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Hell, and Devils, th'are untiling of the House.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Let off the Bottles of Stepony, they may think th'are Guns.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Clap up the middle hatch with the Iron spikes.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Take down the false Stairs.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: Open the Trap-door, that falls into the Common-shoar.

sp.speaker: Drink.
sp.p: Hang up the tenter Hooks.—

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Set the great Chest against the stair Door. [Stephania Whistles, Enter Wenches.]

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: To the great Chest, the great Chest.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: within Heave all together, heave Cats, heave.
Heave Cats, heave— cheerily, cheerily.

sp.speaker: Alon. Gonz. Quak.
sp.p: — Murther, murther, murther.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Oh, you obstreperous Woolves, a Rot consume your Windpipes, y'are louder then the rabble.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: O, this base, this cursed business!

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Cursed bus'ness, thou invincible Fop, thou Brazen headed Ignoramus— Hast thou a mind to be limb'd? one word more, and all the Doors shall fly open: Cursed business, with a pox to ye.
sp.stage: Enter Wenches— And go off again.
sp.p: Come tag-rag-and long-tail, Old Satin, Taffaty, and Velvet, rouze about, charge 'em briskly, showr the Coals on their pates.— He calls Wenching, base cursed bus'ness— Oh you rake Hells, sons of unknown Fathers.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Hell take 'em, they clime the Walls like Cats.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Down with the Tables and Stools upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Sound a Parle, sound a Parle, or they'l break in upon us— There's no hope left.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: A Parle, thou impudent miscreant! false hearted Caytiff I'le rather like a noble Roman Virago, make my House my Funeral pile.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: All are resolv'd not to fight a stroak more, sound a Parle but to gain time.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: To delude the Foe I consent, but never to yield.

div.stage: Sound a Parle, and hang out the White Flag. [A Horn sounds within, and one passes over the Stage with a Flannel Peticoat on a Stick: another Horn sounded on the other side.]

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Hark, they answer us.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Go you Drinkallup, and see what they will demand.

sp.speaker: Drink.
sp.p: Here's a Plenipotentiary desires admittance.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Let him be blinded, and introduc'd by the Postern— Casement— Come fellow Souldiers, lets sit in State, and receive him with undaunted Countenances, as blustring Warriours do, though we are like to dye for fear.
Master of our Ceremonies, introduce the Plenepotentiary.

div.stage: [A dirty fellow led in between two Wenches.]

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Fellow Souldiers 'tis a Maxim in Warr to treat with our Arms in our hands— (Guard, deliver us your Weapons)— and while we talke of peace to prepare for a Battle; therefore Guard go you and mend the backs of the Chairs. [Exeunt Guard.]
Plenipotentiary, be not dismaid with the glittering Splendour of our Court, but boldly deliver what thou hast in Charge.—

sp.speaker: Plen.
sp.p: My Master, the many-headed-monster-Multitude, to save the great effusion of Christian Chamberly, will grant you peace on these terms.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Say on.

sp.speaker: Plen.
sp.p: First, they demand the Dominion of the Straights mouth, and all the Mediterranean Sea— That every Frigot, Fireship, you have, shall strike, furle up their sail, and lye by to the least of their Cock-boats, where-ever they meet, and receive a man aboard to search for prohibited Goods, and permit him to romage fore and oft without resistance.—

sp.speaker: Stepha
sp.p: Umph.— My friends, this is very hard.

sp.speaker: Plen.
sp.p: Secondly, That all their Vessels shall have and enjoy a free-trade into and out of all your Ports without paying any Custom.—

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: The duties of Importation are my greatest Revenue, and must not be parted with.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: But though your People pay for import, we will engage to pay them at going off.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: As we have always done heretofore.

sp.speaker: Plen.
sp.p:
Lastly, That you re-imburse the charge of the War, pay for the Cure of the wounded, and the recov'ry of those that have surfeited on your rotten Ling and Poys'nous Oyl, and allow Pensions
for those that are dismembered— What say ye, Peace, or War?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: War.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: War, War, War.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Return for answer, that we will rather dye at their Feet, then submit to such dishonourable Conditions:— Begon:— And so she pray'd me to tell ye.

sp.speaker: Plen.
sp.p: Though you refuse peace, I scorn to carry back my present,— there. [Throwes out a bunch of Carrets.]

sp.speaker: Drink.
sp.p: We scorn their Courtesies, and their dry toyes.

sp.speaker: Plen.
sp.p: Are ye so fierce? if the Seige continue, you'l Petition for 'em: look for Fire and Sword— And so she pray'd me to tell you.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Arm, Arm, give the word, Arm, Arm.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Arm, Arm.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Arm, Arm, Arm, [Exeunt All.]

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Many a brush have I gon through in my time, but never was any so sharp.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: S'death, our Ammunition's spent, the dear dear dyet-drink's gone.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: And yet these Canibals, more insatiate then the Sea, are not satisfi'd with our best goods; pull up the Harths, and down with the Chimnies.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain to strive.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Thou Cow-hearted cormorant, shall we be all lost for thee?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: No, 'tis for thy obstinacy, thou insatiable shee-Woolf.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Rot your Sheeps blood.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Confound your brutish heart and bacon, face.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Nounz, stir about, or I'le beat thy brains out with my Bottle.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: One word more, and by the Lord, Harry.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Thou dar'st not for thy Blood, thou dar'st not.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: For shame let not the Army see our difference, or thy Cowardise.—

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Pull down the House, and bury them in the Ruines: come along boldly, my dear hearts, follow me, I shall find a time.—

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: To be hang'd— I don't doubt it.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: O save the Syring and the Pot of Turpentine-pills for my sake.— [Exit Bean.]

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Save nothing, cut off your Leggs and throw at 'em. Out with the Exchange Womans Trunk of Perfum'd Linnen which the Old Knight us'd to play hey Gamer Cook in— Out, out; save nothing. [Exit Steph.]

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Fill the old Justices greazy Night-Cap with the Rosary of Beads the Fryer pawn'd here but last Night, and down with 'em.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: I wish they were all Cannon-bullets for their sakes.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Hold, hold, if you throw out the Beads, they'l take us for Papishes, and then there's no Mercy; otherwise we may still hope for pity because we are all of one Religion.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Set the Led Cistern against the Door; all hands to the Cistern, to the Cistern. [Steph. whistles]

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: My Girles, my Daughters.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Fellow Souldiers, dear hearts now for the last push.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: All hands to the Cistern, away▪— [Exeunt all.]

div.stage: Enter all pulling at a Rope.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Hoa up; hoa up; cheerily, cheerily, pluck all together.—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hoa up! hoa up! hoa up!

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Down, down, all hands down, th'are going to spring a Mine. [All run down]

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: There's a fresh Brigade ef sturdy Blood-hounds come from the Butcher-row.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: The Barr of the Door's broke.—

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Barr it with the Constables staffe that lay here last Night.

sp.speaker: Drink.
sp.p: O Mother, save your self, save your self.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Must our mouths be cold then? [She whistles.]

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: All's lost, all's lost.— [Exit Drink.]

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: They break in like a full Sea upon us.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: O Mother, Mother, shift for your self.

sp.speaker: Steph:
sp.p: Name not me: the Justices, and Jaylors, are my very good Friends, and Customers.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ah, there's no trust to Friends now.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: If I dye, I dye, but I pity your tender backs, and grieve for the present want all these young Gallants will have of so many excellent Beauties. [Exeunt Hect. Bean. Mous. and Drink. and return presently.]

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Yet, yet, you may 'scape perhaps.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: The poor hearts fight as if they were all Scanderbegs.]

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: Yet, shift Mother in two minutes, 'twil be too late.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: No, here will I stay, and like a Phaenix, perish in my Nest, the Fates so Decree.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Then let's among 'em, and dye all together, or break through.—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed. [Exeunt all.]

div.stage: A great noyse of fighting, crying Fire, Murther, &c. The Rabble, and Wenches enter fighting. It Rains Fire, Apples, Nuts.— A Constable and Watch enter, and drive all off.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: MIranda, where's your Sister?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I left her on the Dust-Cart-top, gaping after the huge noyse that went by.—

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: It was a dreadful show.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Oh woe, and alass, ho, ho, ho! I'm glad I did not see it though.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Hold in thy breath, and tell thy Vertuous Body, there's no harme down, th'are all reserv'd for thine, and thy Sister Dorindas private use.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: And shall we have 'em all, a-ha! that will be fine i'fads; but if you don't keep'em close, pray Father, we shall never have 'em long to our selves pray; for now ev'ry Gentlewoman runs huckstring to Market, the youth are bought up so fast; that poor Publicans are allmost starv'd, so they are so.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Leave that to my Fatherly Care.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: And shall we have 'em all, ha, ha, he! O good dear hau, how the Citizens Wives will curse us.—

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Miranda, you must now leave this Tom-rigging, and learn to behave your self with a grandeur and state, befitting your illustrious Birth and Quality.— Thy Father, Miranda, was 50 years ago a man of great power, Duke of my Lord Mayors Doggkennel.—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O lo, why Father, Father, are not I Miranda Whiffe, sooth, and arn't you Prospero Whiffe, sooth, Keeper of Bridewell, my Father?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Thy Mother was all Mettle.— As true as Steel, as right's my Legg, and she said thou wert my Daughter; canst thou remember when thou wert Born, sure thou canst not, for then thou wert but three days old.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I'fads, I do remember it Father, as well as 'twere but yesterday.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Then scratch thy tenacious Poll, and tell me what thou findest backward in the misty black and bottomless Pit of time.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Pray Father had I not Four, or Five Women waiting upon top of me, at my Mothers groaning, pray?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Thou hadst, and more Miranda, for then I had a Tub of humming stuff would make a Cat speak.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O Gemine! Father how came we hither?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: While I despising mean, and worldly bus'ness, as mis-becoming my grave Place, Quality, did for the bett'ring of my mind, apply my self, to the secret and laudable study of Nine-pins, Shovel-board and Pigeon-holes— do'st thou give eat Infant▪

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I do, most Prudent Sir.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: My Brother, to whom I left the manage of my weighty state, having learn'd the mysterious Craft of coupling Doggs, and of untying them; and by strict Observation of their jilting carriage, found the time when Venus, Countess, Lady, Beauty, and the rest of my she subjects, were to be oblig'd, by full allowance of their sports, soon grew too Popular, stole the hearts of my currish Vassals, and so became the Ivy-leaf, which cover'd my Princely Issue, and suck'd out all my Juice. Dost observe me Child?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yes, forsooth Father, this story would cure Kib'd-heels.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: This Miscreant, so dry he was for sway, betray'd me to Alonzo, Duke of Newgate; and in a stormy and dreadfull Night open'd my Kenell Gates, and forc'd me thence with thy young Sister, and thy howling self.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Father! did they kill us then, pray Father?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Near the Kenell they dar'd not for the love my dogged Subject bore me.— In short to Newgate we were carry'd,— And thence all in a Cart, without a cov'ring, or a Pad of Straw, to Hyde Park-corner, we were hurri'd there on the stubbed Carkase of a Leafeless Tree, they hoysted us aloft to pipe to winds, whose murm'ring pity whistling back again, did seem to show us cursed kindness.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O poor Father!— But whereof, how did we 'scape Father?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Some Friends we had, and some Money, which gaind the assistance of a great man called Gregoria Dunn ', appointed master of that black design: now luck begins to turn.— But ask no more; I see thou grow'st pinck-ey'd, go in, and let the Nurse lay thee to sleep.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: And shall she give me some Bread and Butter, Father.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Ay, my Child,— Go in.— [Exit Miranda.] So she's fast.— Ariel, what ho my Ariel?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: Hayl most potent Master, I come to serve thy pleasure Be it to lye, swear, steal, pick pockets, or cerep in at Windows—

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: How didst thou perform the last task I set the?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p:
I gather'd the Rabble together, show'd them the Bawdy House, told e'm they us'd to kill Prentices, and make mutton pyes
of 'em— I led them to the Windows, Doors, backward, forward, now to the Sellar, now to the House top— Then I ran and call'd the Constable, who came just as the Rabble broke in, and the defendants were leaping from the Balcony, like Saylers from a sinking Ship. The Duke and his Trayn I clap'd into a Coach.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Are they all taken and safe?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: All safe in several parts of this thy enchanted Castle of Bridewel, and not a hair of 'em lost.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Twas bravely done my Ariel! Whats a Clock?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Great Tom already has struck ten:
Now blest are Women that have men,
To tell fine tale, and warm cold feet,
While lonely lass lyes gnawing sheet.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: We have much to do e're morning come: follow me, i'le instruct thee within.
Before the gorgeous Sun upon▪ House top doth Sneer,
The Laud knows what is to be done, the Laud knows where.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div.head: Act. II.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: OH Sister sister, what have I seen pray?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Some rare sight I warrant.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: From yonder dust-cart-top, as I star'd upon the noyse, I thought it had been fighting, but at last I saw a huge Creature, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O whereof you mean the Coach.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Coach! i'fads, I thought it had been a Fish, I'm sure it was alive, and it ran roaring along, and all the People ran away from it for fear it should eat 'em.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O lo, O lo Sister, O lo!— ha ha he—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why d'ee laugh at one Sister, indeed it had eaten men, for just by our gate it stood still and open'd a great Mouth in the belly of it, and it 'em out all whole:

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Oh but Sister, whereof I can tell you news pray, my Father told me in that Creature was that thing call'd Husband, and we should see it shortly and have it pray, in a Civil way.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Husband, what's that?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Why that's a thing like a man (for ought I know) with a great pair of Hornes upon his head, and my father said 'twas made for Women, look ye.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What must we ride to water upon't, sister?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: No, no, it must be our slave, and give us Golden Cloaths Pray, that other men may lye with us in a Civil way, and then it must Father our Children and keep them.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And when we are so Old and Ugly, that no body else will lye with us, must it lye with us it self?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Ay that it must Sister.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You see my Father gets men to lye with us, is not he a Husband then?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: No, you see he has no Hornes.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: May be he sheds 'em like a Buck, or puts 'em in his pocket like a rich Citizen, because he won't lye with us himself when he can get no body else.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Fie Sister; no! Fathers and Mothers are kinder and wiser now then they were heretofore look ye; for when they see their Daughters will be modish and kind, they provide 'em Gallants themselves to lye with them.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But if we must take those our careful Parents get, only for profit, 'tis as bad as marrying.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: They doe it only 'till they get us Husbands to ease them of the trouble.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O whereof Sister, my Father may spare himself of that trouble, for I am old enough to shift for my self in a civil way, for I was 13. last quarter Sessions, ay and wise enough too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: So we all think i'vads, but they can get us Coaches and Settlements, whereof if we were left to our selves, we should creep into holes, and yet nothing but Bastards.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: If our fathers don't get us Husbands quickly, wee'l make him lye with us himself, shall we sister?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Ay ay, that we will, but lets goe in now, He's about something I long to see the end of, come lets not despair, the flesh is strong.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O for a Husband sister how I long.

div.head: Act. II. Scene. II.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: GOnzalo Oh— my lodging is inchanted.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Mine with a Devil and like your Grace is haunted,
Which plays more tricks then e're the witch my Aunt did.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: First doleful groans at both my ears were lugging.
Then whistling voyce like wind in empty muggin.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Shrieks as of switcheld lass I heard, and anon
Sighs of enchanted ghost like roaring Canon.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: With Princely hoof I knock'd, and noyse did follow,
By which I find O, Heavens! the House is hollow,
My bed of state—

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Of straw you mean— now good my Lord doe not lye.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Millions of devils mov'd, black, white, and motley,
Six legs a piece, sharp claws.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Aye mine were so Sir,
Each tooth a needle, and each eye a saucer.
They stole my shooes, and in a hole I found 'em.
The white possest, black Armies did surround 'em,
Feircely the black attaqu'd, and white defended,
Horrour and death in ev'ry Seam attended.
The nimble black like hopping Devils ventur'd,
Mounted the works, and on the half moon enter'd.
But here the white serty'd as thick as sawdust,
And beat them off.
Then march'd up the red listed Reformadoes,
But what they did I dare not tell for fear.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Sage matrons say, where such kind Foes appear,
The Lord o'th' pasture shall not dye that year.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Unless he's eaten out—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: On large deal board by prudent vermine chosen,
Two Armies more were fighting for my hosen.
If I but offer composition for my sock,
All leave the field, and to my Carkass flock.
No Fairy pinches half so close, nor no Witch.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: 'Tis worse then nettle, sting of Wasp, or Cowitch.

div.stage: Alonzo pulls a Louse out of his neck

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Treason treason, O here's one of the white devils, treason treason, my guard my guard, Oh ho hoe.
sp.l: Fortune has cheated me of all, pize on her,
I am no Duke now, but a poor Prisoner.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Oh what horrid noyse is this assaults our ears.

sp.speaker: 1 De.
sp.l: Where be those boyes,
That make such a noyse,
And won't eat their bread and butter?

sp.speaker: 2 De.
sp.l: Without all doubt.
Th' are hereabout,
Wee'l teach 'em to make such a Clutter.

sp.speaker: 3 De.
sp.l: Who are the ring-leaders, who rules the Boast?

sp.speaker: 4 De.
sp.l: Alonzo the Duke, and another old Toast.

sp.speaker: 1 De.
sp.l: Wee'l put water in their porridge,
And straw in their beds,

sp.speaker: 2 De.
sp.l: Shooes on their feet, and a Comb in their heads.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Wee'l put &c.
And straw &c.
Shooes &c.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: O save me, save me, Gonzalo

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: I would give him the best member I have, to save my self.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: These great He Devils will hearken to no such Composition.

sp.speaker: 1 De.
sp.l: Rogues that from their Liquor shrink,
Shall scorch to death for want of drink.

sp.speaker: 2 Dev.
sp.l: And who with false glass good fellows betray,

sp.speaker: 3 Dev.
sp.l: And tipple small beer in stead of their wine,

sp.speaker: 4 Dev.
sp.l: Then bubble their poor weak brothers at play,
To the whip and the stocks wee'l confine.

sp.speaker: 1 Dev.
sp.l: So poor, so poor, they still shall remain;
Mirth, or good Wine, they shall ne'r have again,
Nor never, oh never, be eas'd of their pain.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: So poor, &c.—
Mirth—
Nor never—

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Never, oh never, eat Custard again!
Oh murthering Sentence— Oh, ho, ho!

sp.speaker: Alonz.
sp.l: Never, never— O Inhumane Correction!
Oh, they begin again— Oh.—

sp.speaker: 1 Dev.
sp.l: Who are the pillars of the wenching Trade?

sp.speaker: 2 Dev.
sp.l: The zealous professor, and brisk City blade.

sp.speaker: 3 Dev.
sp.l: The Gallants, and Bullies,
Do often grow poor, and bare, and bare.

sp.speaker: 4 Dev.
sp.l: But these Canters, and close City Cullios
Are ne'r without Money, or Ware.

sp.speaker: 1 Dev.
sp.l: What Slave permits
Such Hypocrites
In peace to tast of all our sweets?

sp.speaker: 2 Dev.
sp.l: In the midst of their joyes, they discoveries fear,

sp.speaker: 3 Dev.
sp.l: And their Wives, if th'ave any, shall make the score clear.

sp.speaker: 4 Dev.
sp.l: With Claps, and with Duns, we torment them all day,
And at night we take them and their Doxies away.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: With Claps &c.—
And at night &c.—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Pox o'the Devil, 'tis too true, they did take our Doxies away.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Ay, and I would procure 'em a whole Regiment, for my Ransome.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Alass, they were but Oysters before their meale; besides they were so rotten, they would melt in their mouthes, all their bones were turn'd to gristle: We are kep'd for the standing Dish.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Nay, then I am safe enough, for I have no more standing Dish, then a post, my hearts no bigger then a Pins-head.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: My poore Boy Quakero's, gone too, Oh, ho, ho!

sp.speaker: 1 Dev.
sp.l: Say, say,
Shall we take up these Rogues, and Carry them away,
With a tory, rory, Tory, rory, rory, Red-Coats?

sp.speaker: 2 Dev.
sp.l: Aye, aye.

sp.speaker: 3 Dev.
sp.l: Aye, aye.

sp.speaker: 4 Dev.
sp.l: Aye, aye.

sp.speaker: 1 Dev.
sp.l: Aye, aye.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: With a Tory, rory, Tory, rory, rory, rory.

sp.speaker: 2 Dev.
sp.l: No, No,
'Till we show them their Crimes, let e'm stay.
With a Tory, rory, Tory, rory, rantum, scantum.

sp.speaker: 3 Dev.
sp.l: Let 'em stay.

sp.speaker: 4 Dev.
sp.l: Let 'em stay.

sp.speaker: 1 Dev.
sp.l: Let 'em stay.

sp.speaker: 2 Dev.
sp.l: Let 'em stay.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: With a Tory, rory, Tory, rory, rory, rory.

sp.speaker: 1 Dev.
sp.l: Cabbage is windy, and Mustard is strong,
But a Lass with a wide Mouth, and a liquorish Tongue.
Will give thee the Palsie, though never so young.
Then first let their Pride, let their Pride come along.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Cabbage.—
But a Lass—
Will give—
Then first—

div.stage: Enter Pride, represented by a Painted, gaudy Woman, with a Glass in her hand.

sp.speaker: Pride.
sp.l: Lo here, here is Pride, that first lest them aside,
An honest true Trojan, and then she dy'd.

div.stage: Enter Fraud, a female Quaker Sings.

sp.speaker: Fraud.
sp.l: With upright look, and speech sincere,
In publick, I a Saint appear.
But in private I put out the light,
And I serve for a Whore, or a Baud.
I have taught them to cheat, Swear, and Fight,
For by Yea, and by Nay, I am Fraud.

div.stage: Enter Rapine, drest like a Padder, with a Pistole in his hand.

sp.speaker: Rapine.
sp.l: Send out a Scout
To yonder Hill.
Stand, and deliver.
You dogg, must I wait.
I'm thy fate:
Dispatch, or I'l send thee to Hell.
From Fraud, they thus proceed to force.
And then I Rapine, guide their Course.

div.stage: A man drest all in Red, with two Bloody Daggers in his hands, and his Face and Hands stain'd with blood.

sp.speaker: Murther.
sp.l: Wake Duncan! would thou couldst.
Disguis'd with blood, I lead them on,
Vntil to Murther they arrive.
Then to the Gallows they run.
Needs must they go, whom the Devils drive.
Alass poor Mortals.
They gape like the Earth, in the Dogg-dayes.
What a rare life the Frogg has?
Drawer, Drawer.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.l: Anon, Anon.

sp.speaker: 1 Dev.
sp.l: Give 'em drink, or they'r gone,
E'r their torment's began.
Pour, pour, pour, pour.
Heark, heark, how it hisses,
See, see, how it smoaks:
Who refuses such Liquor as this is,
May he pine, may he pine, may he pine
'Till he choakes.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Hearks, &c.

div.stage: The Devils sing, and Dance round Alonzo, and Gonzalo.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Around, around.
Around, around, around.
Let's sing, and tear the ground,
There's no such sport below,
Where sinfull mortals go.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Oh, oh, are you alive my Lord Duke.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I cannot tell, Ah, ha,— Feel me, feel me, what a drench they gave us, sure 'twas Spirit of Brimstone.— I am all in a flame.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.p: Their design, is to roast us as some do Geese, by putting a hot Iron in their bellies, I begin to drip, they may make a Sop in the Pan already.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Anon they'l cut off slivers from us, as they did from the whole Ox, in St. Iames's Fair.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis intollerable: methinks I hear a great she Devil, call for Groats worth of the Crispe of my Countenance.— They are all for Gristle.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Another cries Six peny-worth of the brown, with Gravy, Shalot, and Pepper, Oh there's a Collop gone!

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Shalot, and Pepper, was well though of, for if I am not well season'd, there's no eating of me.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Indeed old Lord, you have a kind of Ven'zon haugou.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: How can it be otherwise, my Lord, when I'me roasted with the guts in my belly?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: If Shat'lin, or Locket had us, what Olio's, Raggous, and Pottages, would they make?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: So new a Dish never came from France, they would get the Devil and all by us.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: We should out-stink French Cheese.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
O help help, here's Raw-head and Bloody bones, the Master Cook of Hell. [A noise of horrid Musick; a Devil arises with a Crown of Fire.] Sings.
Arise, arise, ye Subterranean Feinds,
Come claw the backs, of guilty hinds:
And all ye filthy Drabs, and Harlots rise,
Which use t' infect the Earth with Puddings, and hot Pies;
Rise ye who can devouring glasses frame,
By which Wines pass to th' hollow Womb, and Brain;
Engender Head-akes, make bold elbows shake;
Estates to Pimples, and to desarts turne.
And you whose greedy flames mans very entrals burne,
Ye ramping queans, who ratling Coaches take,
Though y'ave been fluxed 'till Head and Body shake.
Come Clap these Wreches 'till their parts do swell:
Let Nature never make them well.
Cause Leggs, and Arms to pine, cause loss of hair,
Then make them howl with Anguish, and sad groans.
Rise and obey, rise and obey, Raw head and bloody bones.
[Exit Devils] Devils arise with Bellows, and blow Alonzo, and Gonzalo, off the Stage.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: Act III.
Scene I.
div.stage: Enter Stephania, with a Pitcher, Beantosser, and Moustrappa, all drunk.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.l: THere was a noble Marquess,
Took up his Maidens carkass,
Fast by the Fire side.
A very homely Damsel,
Her lips were soft as Lambs wool,
Or marrow Pasty-fri'd.
sp.p: This is but a kind of a doleful Tune, to beat Hemp to, but hang't lets squeeze the Picher, here's to thee my doughty Amazon.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Right reverend Trot-up-and-down, I'le do thee reason here Moustrappa.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Come bouze it about, and a fico for the Justice. Fortunes a Whore, and will be kind to her Sisters.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: Of the first Five men, we met Three were Iohns, and Four of those were Cukolds,— Which is a good sign, and so squeez the juice.—

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: A strong point of Consolation, let me kiss thee for that, thou pretty, pocky, well favour'd Crack.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.l: Fill the Dish Molly,
And think of a Cully.
Here's a health to the best.
Give us more Drink, a Surgeon that's jelly.
And a pox take the rest.
Molly fill.
We cry still,
Fill again, and drink round.
'Till we empty the Pitcher, and fill up the Crown.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Hold, hold, our Sister is grown hollow hearted, and like a jilting Quean, forsakes us in our Tribulation.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: 'Tis ev'n what I look'd for,— The last Dish came as slow, and frothy, as the last words of a declaring Quaker.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: When the Spirit sinks down his Throat, and rattles like the departing Water in a leaky Pump.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Blame her not, you here she is sound still, ha! wilt thou so? Knocks the Pitcher. Why thats very fair,— She sayes, she will do w'ye for a Groat a time, 'till you are not able to stand: I'le be hang'd if the worst Jugg in Town, will do cheaper.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p:
Look Moustrappa Weeps,— Hang losses, though our Dancing Schooles ruin'd, we have sav'd our Instruments: And as
ong as Men drink, and Women paint, we shall still jog on.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: There are more of our Dulcimers thump'd ev'ry Night in Covent-Garden, then there are Ghittars scrap'd in a Week, in Madrid; therefore I say, staunch thou false hearted misbeleiving Jewes-Trump, do not many industrious Females live well by bidding Gentlemen welcome to Town, singing at their Chamber doors?

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: And trucking their English small Wares, for French Toyes.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: O this was a dreadful bout for poor Moustrappa. In robbing me, they pillag'd six Brokers: ruind my Credit and quite kill'd my old dealer, honest Jack the Mercer; for just as I had brought his Body to such a state, that none else would touch him so that I could set my own rates, they took me from him; the French Farendine, he gave me for a Gown is gone too.— But let the World rub, when 'tis at worst 'twill mend.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: The devil take thee, for putting me in mind of my losses: hang me if I can forbear weeping too.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Then thou art in danger of drowning for the water's above thy mouth, and there's no passage by the Nose, for the bridge was down long ago; and so she prai'd me to tell ye.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: My friend is a brisk French Merchant, I knew him a Taylors Trotter: but from 3 Ounces of Jessimy-butter, halfe a Pound of Powder, and 6 pair of Jessimy-Gloves, by cheating the King of his Customes, and his fellow Subjects of their Money, he's come to his beaten Farendine Suit ev'ry day: had not this befall'n me, I had reduc'd him to his first being, and I had hazarded the saving of his Soul, by the ruine of body, and estate.— But he is but repreiv'd,— the pox will take him, for he is a Termagant at laced Mutton.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p:
Mischeif light on ye both, for minding me of my losses; there was scarce a Manchild in Town, gentle, or simple, from Fifteen to Threescore, that did not pay me Tribute.— When I walk'd the Streets, the Shop-keepers bow'd, the Prentices wink'd; If five, or six Gallants stood in the way, Lord what rustling and cringing was there to Madam Stephania?— Aunt, cries one, how does my little Neece?— The Aunt, and the Neece, may both be damn'd, for any thing you care to please: me he slips a Guinny. When shall we cut up the Giblet Pye? cryes another.— Go y'are a wag, cry I: there's halfe a Peece. Saies a third, is there never a fresh Runlet
tap'd? yes quoth I, but you shall be hang'd e're you lick your lips with it; and so she praid me to tell ye: still something's coming, for every now and then slips in a close thriving Tradesman, look ye Mrs. quoth he, I do not use these things, but the case is thus, I'le be at a word, I want a Wench; give me good sound ware, here's your Money, ready Money: I won't build Sconees, and bilk you, as your Gentlemen Bullies do, let me have weight and measure, one words as good as a thousand. Well quoth I, put your bus'ness into my hand, I'le use a Conscience, aye, and I did too, for as I hope for freedome; sometimes I have hardly got 8 d. in the Shilling. But such were sure Customers, they never left me for fear of discovery. Oh! I could tell you such stories of Vestry-men, and Burgesses, as would make the Bells ring backwards, i'faith,— Me, and my bus'ness, was the whole talke of the Town, but all was kep'd secret, not a word mention'd, unless 'twer in some Coffee-house, or the Streets.— But now they all forsake me— but 'twill rub out when 'tis dry, and so I squeeze.—

div.l: Tough Hemp must we beat?
Dry Bread must we eat,
And be bumbled, and jumbl'd, and grumbl'd at too, too, too.
And drink nothing, but Wat, Wat, Water that's cold?
Then Harry, and Mary, be merry and cheery, as long's we can do, do, do.
And drive away sorrow, untill we are old.
Come bouze it about, and lets squeeze out the Pitcher.
He's a Rogue that stands out, and shall ne'r be the Richer.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Heres Ten go downs upon Re. Moustrappa.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: Put rem to't or I renounce thee.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Renounce me Puss, not pledge me, thou salt Suburbian Hackney, not pledge me.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: Well Mrs. Beantosser, I hant stood three years at Livery, and been hyr'd for 6 d. a side on Holy daies▪ by Chimny-Sweepers, and Coblers 'Prentices, I hant so.—

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Who has Mrs. Gillian flirt! Mrs. To and agen, who has?

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: I name no body, but touch a gall'd Horse, and hel wince.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p:
But I know who has been taken up in the common, and rode
so many heats that they got the French, fashions that was ev'n your own sweet Monkey face, I scorne to go behind your crooked back to tell you so.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Fight Dog, fight Bear, still here's the juice of life.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: I never danc'd naked at the French house for Mild-Six- pences, goody Lerry-come-twang.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Out, out, that's old, that's old.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Nor I never walk'd the Streets at Night, stark naked in a Buckram Suit, trim'd with black Ribons at the Codpeice, Mrs. Gincrack, Mrs. Nimble-go-through.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: No, no, that thou didst not old Tru-peny, that was the Tailors Wife,— but 'tis old too.—

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Who dress'd her self in mans cloahes to commit with another Womans Husband under his natural Wifes nose, not you?

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: Who goes ev'ry Night upon Water to see men swim on their backs, and show beastly triks, not Beantosser, no?

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Who uses to be drunk at Tavernes tear her friends Wigs, and then give all the Money, she has for a frisk with the Drawer, not Mrs. Betty Moustrappa?

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: Who storms the Fort in private with a Leathern Gun.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Go y'are a mean spirited Crack, to be kep'd by a Club of Prentices: and so she praid me to tell ye.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: 'Tis better to receive small ware then give broad Gold, as hou doest like a silly Trapes.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: The foul names thy own, and I'le dash it down thy Throat.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: Help, help, murther, she'l murther me.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold, keep the Kings Peace, I say keep the Peace, do you not tremble to use such bug words, if any body should hear you it would bring a scandal on the house, and make 'em think us Whores, Restore her nose Moustrappa, and you Beantosser, give back her Eye-brows: I say squeeze the juice, and let acts of Hostility cease, I was governaunt at home, and I will be justice of Peace here.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: I will have no Justice.—

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Beantosser be orderly, and thou shalt be my Clerk.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: No private bribery to Corrupt Justice, and to show that I desire all things may he done without favour or selfishness, let Beantosser be hang'd, and give me her cloathes, and so I squeeze.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Justice, an't please your Worship, I'le swear the peace against her.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Bear back, bear back, good People don't press upon the Court.— Constable stand by me, and go fetch the offender before me.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: I command thee to come before my Lord Justice. No— good people will ye ayd and assist me.— We are resolved to assist Mr. Constable Beantosser to the death.— La you there now.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: The Justice is an Ass, the Constable a Sheepshead, and all the good People a Whore, and a Baud: and so she pray'd me to tell ye.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Grant me a humming Warrant to compel her to come before you volens nolens of her own accord.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: How, how, thou art an evil Counsellor, and a Traytor; thou seekest to deprive me of my honourable Imployment by force quoth'a, no, some wiser then some: I am a Justice of peace, and must keep the peace. But if I grant a Warrant to compel, I break the Peace. If she comes, she comes, all must be done in a peacefull way: Volens nolens quoth'a.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Right Worshipfull, 'tis a common way to grant a Warrant.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Ay, ay, 'tis so common that we Magistrates are all the worse for't, it makes justice so cheap that no People of fashion care for using any.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: An't please your Worship,

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Please me, and please thy self, I say still.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: To accept this small present?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Hay! more Plots, how darst thou corrupt Justice, thou Treacherous Strumpet! devour the bowels that gave thee Suck? Now do I know she wants Justice, because she would buy it— Clerk, take up the Bribery, and give it to the poor: since my Clerk is absent I will vouchsafe to do it my self.— But did this audacious Tatter-de-mallion declare with her own Corporal voyce, that she would not come before us?

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: I did, and I do again send thee word by my self, that thou shalt come before me,— If thou wilt not, I command thee to stay there,— and so I squeeze.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p:
Does the Rebel send word, her self being present, that
she will not appear?— it stands not with our high place to put up such affronts.— Head-Constable, knock her down, and keep the Peace. Bean. and Moust. fight.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: So now the whole Courts in an uproar, fight, 'till the Devil part you.— Hold, hold, fall off, and unite against the common Enemy.

div.stage: Enter Hectorio, and Drinkallup, drunk and Singing.

sp.speaker: Drink.
sp.l: Francky, was his name a,
And Francky was his name a;
His Beard was black, and his Gills were Red,
And his Bill was all of the same a.
With weapon full sharp, he fought 'till he was dead,
With a Heycock of the game a,
And Francky was his name a,
And with weapon &c.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Francky's dead, and gon a,
Poor Franchy's dead, and gon a:
Thy browes are black, and thy lips are Red,
And thy bellies soft as the down a.
Let me be thy Worm, and at every turn,
I will tickle thy flesh, and bone a.
Then prithee cease they moan a,
Since Francky's dead, and gon a.
Let me &c.—

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Silence in the Court, to keep a sound Peace, I make you both my High-Constables of Westminister.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Then by Virtue of my Warrant, which shall be made when we are at leasure, bring those disturbers of the Peace before me.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Woman, leave thy babbling, and come before the Justice.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: Hectorio, be uncover'd in the Court, and obey the Officers.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: What Court? what Officers?

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Why Stephania is Justice of Whorum, and we are both Head-Constables.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Then Officers, look to your Throats, for there will be above Ten thousand up in Armes to Night. Sings.— And their bellies soft as the down a.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: He has confest, and shall be hang'd 'till he's dead. Come thou Rake-hell, villain, dog, where are they, what's their design, who leads 'em on, who brings 'em off, make his Mittimus, before he answers, and send him to Tyburn.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Old touch and go, why so hasty?— My Lord Bacchus leads 'em on: my Lady Venus brings 'em off: their design is to rise up in their Beds, at midnight, to stab all the Women, and be head all the Virgins they Catch.

sp.speaker: Drink.
sp.p: Sings— With a Hey-cock of the game a.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: O inhumane Canibals!

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: Let 'em do their worst, the Women will be hard enough for 'em, man to man.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: And I believe the Virgins had notice of their design, for there is not one left in my Liberties: Head-constables, dispatch this Westminster Wedding, I say, tye 'em up.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Won't your Worship examine the Woman?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: I say, take her away, shes a Pick-pocket I know, by her lac'd Shooes: besides, heark ye, she's a Witch, she carries an enchanted Ring about her which turns Rich men to beggers, and makes an Ass of a Justice of Peace.

sp.speaker: Drink.
sp.p: Gentlemen of the Jury, this Villain is no honester then he should be, he rob'd me of a dozen of precious Turpentine guilt Nutmegs, and a Pewter Squirt.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Which is flat felony, for that's the Iron work to her Plough, without which it must stand still, and her Familiars must starve: and so she prayd me to tell ye.

sp.speaker: Drink.
sp.p: But because the old Rogue is a true friend to the Chuck-office, I care not much if I save him, therefore you may bring in the Fellony, Man-slaughter.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I am a Witness for the King, and so lets squeeze all round.

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: Art thou her Cozen after the flesh?

sp.speaker: Drink
sp.p: No, he is my Husband's Brother, for they tumbl'd both in one Belly.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p:
Then thy Husband has a whole Legion of Brothers, for halfe
the Town have tumbl'd in the same place: and so she pray'd me to tell ye.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Woman, put me in good Bail, or take her away Jaylor.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Hold, hold, what Bail dost thou demand?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Two substantial Citizens, Aldermens fellowes, or common Councel men, but no Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Drink.
sp.p: No Cuckolds, Jaylor take me away,— hold, heark you, If you'l take a Hundred that are Cuckolds, by the help of my friends here they shall be produc'd presently.— Nay don't bob down your heads, I did but try him.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: No, no! no Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: This is flat Tyrany, thou maist as well demand a Tribute of Maiden-heads in the Teens: but Miracles are ceas'd.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: What is this notorious talking Rogue in for?

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: For Robbing of the Vestry.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: How Sirrah, who made you a Church-Warden?

sp.speaker: Mous.
sp.p: 'Tis but a Vestry matter, and may be agreed at the next Tavern.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Who will pay Scot and lot, as they say, and serve in all under Offices of trouble, if every Rascal shall usurp that very Office, where they may reward themselves?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Ay, without Authority, or paying a farthing for't, when 'tis well known substantial House-keepers have given hundreds or't.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Yes, and thriv'd upon't too, with a blessing on their pious endeavours.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Head Constables take 'em away to Limbo.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: We defie thee, and thy Head-Constables, to mortal battle.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Then blood will ensue: and so she prai'd me to tell ye.— Sound a charge, and keep the Peace.

div.stage: Musick plays, they dance, and Exeunt.

div.head: Scene. II. Act. III.
div.stage: Enter Ariel, and Quakero. Ariel Sings.
div.l: FOllow me, and follow me, hey jolly Robin.
The Moon shines bright,
And Women are light,
And most men had rather eat then fight.
Then leave off your Coging.
And follow me, a follow me hey jolly Robin.

sp.speaker: Quak.
sp.l: Four corners on my bed,
Four beauties therely spred.
If any evil come to me,
O goodness sweet deliver me.
sp.p: Blessed be thanked, it is now again departed; this Charme I learn'd in the days of my Paganis-me, before I attain'd to the inworking and the bowel-yernings of the outgoing of the over-flowings; but now that I am mounted into the Saddle, and exalted to the House top, and lifted on the sounding Tub of reformation, I am above the Fruit-mongers of the hard Streets of stony-heartedness: and I am above thee Satan— ha it cometh again.
sp.l: Turn thy Stocking, and tye thy Shooe hard.
Thy mouth being wash'd, and wip'd thy beard.
Come away, come lets be jogging.
Bo, bo, bo, bo,
Heark, heark, how the Bettern bellowes
Now is the time for good fellows.
To it— to it— to it— to it.
The Citizens Wife.
Leads a merry, merry life,
While her Husband at home does grunt and groan.
Whoo whoo oo oo oo— whoo ooo oo.
Alass poor man he is sick of the yellowes.
Cuckoe, cuckoe.
Heark, heark, what the little birds tells us.
Cuckoe, cuckoe, cuckoe.

sp.speaker: Quak.
sp.p: Torment me no more thou Hobgoblin, thou Robin-good-fellow, thou Will with a wisp, thou Spright, thou Fairy, thou, thou nothing, thou something— ha, what should this be, assuredly here hath been some Crouder slain against his consent, or murther'd wrongfully, or else 'tis the Soul of some profane Singing-man that rejoyceth and gibeth at the death of the Duke my father, Oh! O! O! it comes again.
sp.l: Youth, youth of mortal race, give ear,
Thy Daddies dead, thy Daddies dead.
To Stocks his feet, to Pillory his Ear,
To whip of thong his flesh is ay turned;
And tough battoon does thump his bone.
O hone, O hone, O hone, O hone.
Then little youth Nandy.
Drink Ale and Brandy.
His knell is hourly rung on his back.
Heark now I hear it, thwick, thwick, thwack,
Thwick &c.— thwack.

sp.speaker: Quak.
sp.p: This dolefull madrigal sayes my Father is in Limbo, that is Mortus est, that is, he is dead, that is, he is departed, he is gone, he is fled, he is no more; He is, he is, I say, he is, that is, he is not.

lg.l: His feet Stock-fish, his ears Pilchards, his flesh
Thornback, and Tough Battoon does thump his bone.
O hone, O hone, O hone, O hone.

sp.p: Friend Quakero, this is no mortal business, though thou hast done Satan right noteable service in perverting many, beleive him not, I say believe him not: hast thou forgot how it was resolv'd in a full dispute, where a friend, ev'n Guly Penno, declared that Satan was a lyer, nay thou hast not forgot, beleive him not, yet I will go to find out and be satisfi'd in the truth of the lye.

sp.speaker: Ariel.
sp.p: Thwick, thwick, thwick, &c. Exit Ariel.

sp.speaker: Quak.
sp.p: Hark, it is there again, it luggeth me by the Ears, even as a Swine is lugged by a Mastiffe-dog: or as one of your wicked Idolatrous Misses is led by the rattling of a guilt Coach, or as, as I say, or as ah ha em, or as ah a aa.
So much for this time. Exit Quakero.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: Act IV.
Scene. I.
div.stage: Enter Prospero, and Ariel. Prospero eating a peece of Bread and Butter.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: NOw does the charm'd impostume of my Plot
Swell to a head, and begin to suppurate,
If I can make Mantua's Infant Duke,
Switchel my young giglet Dorinda.
Sincere Quakero to my power bends,
And shall with my discreet Miranda yoak,
Or be tormented ever here,
In my enchanted Castle of Bridewellow.
Great pity 'tis— for he's a pretty fellow.
Ariel!

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: What says my mighty and most potent Master.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: How do these right puissant Ragamuffins bear their durance?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: The Duke with haughty meen, for lack of food,
Sits cracking Fleas, and sucking of their blood.
With him is good Gonzale.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Is he so, Adsbud. Throwes away his Bread and Butter, in passion.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: From eyes of Glass the gummy tears that fall
Down Iv'ry beard like Christal vermine crawl.
The rest are picking strawes, and so that's all.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Where is Quakero, that young Princely Sprout?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Like Lanthorn-jack I led him all about,
And now he's blowing of his nailes without.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Alass poor Trout.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: I have so gall'd 'em, 'twould make your Graces hair stand on end to see how they look; though your heart more stony was then Coblers wax i'th' dog days, 'twould make it in your mouth dissolve like Culvers dung.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Do'st thou think so Spirit?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: It makes mine open and shut, open and shut, like a fat Hostesses greazy Pouch, so it does: and then the poor old Gentleman and her daughters have almost torne one another to peeces— I pity them.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: And I will— hast thou that art so young a Spirit, so little too— had a touch a feeling of their Case, and shall not I have a relish?— Well, Ariel go let a Table be brought to them furnish'd with most sumptuous Cates, but when they try to eat, let two great Babboons be let down with ropes to snatch it away.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: O Sir Punchanello did that at the Play-house.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Did he so— then bend thy ayry ear. whispers

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: More toyle— I pry'thee now let me mind thee of thy promise then— where is my Two-penny Custard?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Ho now moody, doe'st thou murmure?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: No my Lord!

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Thou ly'st, Malignant thing, thou dost.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: I pri'the my Lord, ben't so touchy.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Hast thou forgot the hairy Woman I freed thee from, who sent thee ev'ry morning down her Gormandizing throat with a Candle and Lanthorn, to tread the Ooze of the salt deep?— At other times she made thee pass up against the strong Northern blasts, when the capacious Bay was bak'd with brandy 'till thou hadst clear'd thy passage to her nose, on whose sulph'rous top thou fat'st Singing like a little Chimny Sweeper, hast thou forgot her?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: No my dread Lord.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: If thou more murmur'st, in some small dimple of her Cheek I'le peg thee, where Twelve Sommers more thou shalt lye stewing like a Maggot in a Holland Cheese.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: O pardon great Sir this once, and I will be a good Boy, and never do so more.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p:
Then do as I commanded, but make hast least the Conjurers of to'ther House steal the Invention— thou know'st they snatch
at all Ingenious tricks.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: I fly most potent Sir. Exit Ariel flying.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Now for the infant Duke of Mantua. Hipolito my Child come forth.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Anan, anan, forsooth— you Sir, don't you stir the Nickers, I'le play out my game presently.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Come gentle youth, exalt thy ducal chin, for thou shalt have a Wife my boy.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: A Wife Sir! what's that, I never saw it?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: No my boy, but they are now so common, young men can hardly walk the streets for them.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Don't go away, you Sir, I do but stay for a Wife, and then Ile play out my game— O good Sir, let me have it quickly.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: And so thou shalt, for my daughters sake; if he should know Wives were growing out of fashion, I fear he would not marry, for the stripling has a gentile fancy, I see by the neatness of his cloathes.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Will it play at Bullet with me?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Ay and Cat, and Trap-ball too.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: What is it like Sir? what is it like?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: 'Tis so inconstant I scarce know what to liken it to, 'tis still unsatisfi'd, restless and wrigling like an Eel.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: O pray let me have it then; I love Eels mightily.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: But like an Eel 'twill slip from thee.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: But I'le bite it by the tail then, and shake it 'till it lies still.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: A shrew'd youth! well thou shalt have it, 'tis beautiful as a Colly-flower, but like that too, when 'tis kep'd long, nothing is more unpleasant.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: O Sir! I won't keep it long.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: A very hopeful Lad!— But it won't part from thee.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Then I'le beat it, and kick it, and run away from't.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Modishly said y'gad, still hopeful— but she'l save thee that trouble, and leave thee as soon any other will keep her; for she's wild and skittish as an unbackt Colt.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Is it like a Colt? O Lemine! then I'le ride upon't.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: A lass poor youth! thou wilt soon be tir'd, and thrown off.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: No Sir, I shall never be weary of Riding; and I'le hold so fast by the Mane and the Tail, that I won't fall off.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: O sie, you must not use it like a Beast.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: What must I do with it then?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Why you must eat and drink with it.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: What is it a Fork, and an Earthern-Pot then?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: No, but she may make Forkes, and crack too many Pots.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Then she shall teach me to make Forks.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Hold there,— you must enjoy none but her.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Enjoy, ah ha! enjoy! what a word is there? enjoy! O rare!— what is enjoy Sir?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Why, that is to be happy.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Enjoy to be happy, then I'le enjoy all the Wives in the World;— For I love to be happy Sir: enjoy!

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: I'le tell you more hereafter; go in and read your Horn-book, that Treatise of Abstruse Philosophy I gave you last.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: I go forsooth. Exit Hypolito.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Now by my best hopes, a shrew'd youth, a very shrew'd youth, and a notable head-peace— I'm glad he's grown so prudent. If all that Marry in this Age of liberty were so Politick, we should see better times.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: O lo! o lo! o lo! Oh, ho, ho, ho!

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: What's the matter? what grand intrigue of Fate can reach to the disturbance of thy manly Soul?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Manly Soul, quoth a, 'twould disturb any mans Soul: I'me undone Sir, while I was talking with you about a Wife, Tom Bully stole away my stones.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Hah thy stones, what stones?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Why my bowling stones. O ho ho, now I can't teach my Wife to play Nickers.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: I'me glad 'tis no worse; O fie, fie my Lord, you must leave off this boyes Play now, and learn to play with Children; go, go in.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: By never, I'le pay that Rogue Tom Bully, when I catch him.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Now I must instruct my Daughters.
Long sleeps and pleasures follow ev'ry Novice:
But plots and cares perplex grave men of Office.
Ye Gods!
More blest are men of mean and low condition,
Then Bridewell-keeper is, or sage Magician.

div.head: Act IV. Scene. II.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: OH Sister! I have such a twittering after this Husband,
And my mouth doth so run in a civil way.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Are you not breeding Teeth Sister?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Zooks, if I am the King, shall know't.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: ‛ Vads Sister, ever since my Father told me of it, which is at least six Hours ago, I can't rest Day, nor Night, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Its hole's hereabout, whereof looky' my Father said that it should get me with Child pray.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O lo! get you with Child, what's that?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I can't tell, but I do so shake and laugh when I think of't.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Heigh ho! whereof Sister you are affraid?— Let it come to me, vads Sister I won't be affraid.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Zooks Sister, if my Father should send a hundred to get me with Child in a civil way, I wouldn't be affraid.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O but Sister, whereof looky', my Father said that a Husband was wild as a Cock-Sparrow or a Curl'd-Lamb, that he did now pray.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Then I would chirrip to't, and make it hop, and stroak it, and make it wag its tayl and Cry blea, 'till it 'twas as tame as a little Lap-dog, but my Father says they are always gentle at home: and wild abroad.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Whereof Sister heark ye, now lets leave this idle talk, and play the Scotch Morice.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Then I'le play forward, and backward, for that's the way now.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: No I won't play Boyes play,— I'le tell you what, you should be a School Mistriss, and—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No Sister, no I'le tell you what? You should be a Citizens Wife pray, and so I should be a Lord looky', and I should come in a Golden-Coach and be your Husbands Customer.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Ay ' vads that's pretty.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: So I should meet you at the Play-House, and say Madam looky' 'tis a thousand pitties such a glazing Di'mond of beauty should be the Slave of a dull Mechanick Cit. and cry what d'ee lack? Whereof you should cry then, O Lord Sir, you are mistaken Zooks.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O Lord Sir, you are mistaken Zooks!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Then I should say Dam'ee Madam! you are a necklace for a Prince, I'le settle Three Pounds a Year upon you, and you shall have a Silver Baby, and a Silver house, and eat nothing but Golden Custards, and Silver-Stew'd-Pruines: then you should say whereof you have got a Wife of your own, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Then you should say whereof you have gotten a wife of your own my Lord.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Then I should throw my Wig, and say, Oh Madam! if you love me, name her not. She's so dull and musty, the very thought of her will make me swoun, Damher. But you I doat upon. So then you should let me lye with you in a Civil way.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O ay, ay, I love that y'vads!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And then another should lye with you, and another, so at last you should be catch'd in a Baudy-house with your Husbands under Prentice looky', and so be brought to Bridewell as Mrs. Tweedlebum was t'other day.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: No, no, Sister, I wont play so— I'le tell y' what, lets play Truss-fayl, do pray now Sister.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Come then, I'le lye down first.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Truss.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Fayl.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Send me well upon my Grey Nags taile. O Sister, Sister! here's the Husband thing coming.

div.stage: Enter Hypolito reading gravely in a Horn-Book.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Looky, looky, O sweet Father its Leggs are twice as long as ours.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What's that before so trim'd up with yellow Pissabeds, and green Blew Bottles.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: See, see it pulls off half its head.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Run Sister, run, I'me so affraid 'twill pull your head off too.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Zooks! I would rather lose a hundred Heads if I had 'em, then stir a foot.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Oh! it looks angry, I'me so affraid for you Sister.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Fear not me, if I offend it, I'le ly down and paw it with my Four-feet, as our Shock does when we beat it.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Miranda, Miranda!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O Sister! my Father calls you,— whereof she sayes she won't come for'oth.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: She fibs, she fibs Father,— I wou'd come, but I am not here for'oth— you spiteful pissabed Slut.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But you are here for'oth.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I wonder y'are so simple Sister, as if I could not tell where I am better then you— for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I will take Husband first that I will.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Hussey, am not I the Elder?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Then you shou'dn't set your Wit against a Child.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Well then Sister, I'le tell y'what, wee'l play heads or tails, who goes first, that's fair now, e'nt it?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ay, and she that don't win shall lose and keep the door.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Well ther's a good Girle, now toss up.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: A ha! my tails turn'd up, you must watch.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Good dear Sister have done quickly, prithee do for because you know why Sister. Exit Miranda.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Prospero has often told me, Nature makes nothing in vain, why then is this kip kap here— tis not aw nor e nor oo, nor lm n o-q-py you— it strangely puzles me; I'le ask him when I see him next.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Thing, thing, fine long thing▪

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Bessy come bunny, come buy me some lace Sugarcandy, Cloves and Mace. Sure I am ready for a Wife now, I can read my abstruse Horn Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O Rare thing, it talkes just like one of us.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Ha— what thing is that? Sure 'tis some Infant of the Park, drest in her Mothers gayest beams of Impudence, and sent down here to play at Hemp and Beetle; but stay, is not this that thing call'd Wife? What art thou, thou fleering thing?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alass I am a Woman, and my Father says I must be a Wife in a Civil way, pray thing don't be angry.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Angry, no, I'le sooner break my Trapstick; mun if thou art that thing call'd Wife, which troubles poor men so that they can't Wench in quiet— Prospero says that I must enjoy thee.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: If thou art that thing call'd Husband which art alwayes sullen and niggardly at home, but merry and expensive abroad. which feedst a Wife with tripe and Cowes heels, and treatest a Mrs. with Woodcock and Teale, and fine things, and at last turnest off a Wife with just enough to buy Bread and Cheese and worsted Farendine, but maintainst thy Miss like a Princess, my Father says thou must get me with Child for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Get thee with Child, O lo! whats that?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Whereof I can't tell, but I think you must dig it out of the Parsly-bed.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Show me the Parsly-bed then.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I won't, you ha, got nothing to dig with: you said you must enjoy me, what's that pray?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Why Prospero says you are like a Colt, and then you should be backt.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Phoe, I won't play so.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Won't you, then look to't, for you are but a Colly-flower, and though y'are so proud to day you'l stink to morrow.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Zooks this is the filli'st Husband-thing I ever saw: I'le run into the Garden, and teach him more wit in a civil way.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Nay if you run from me like an Eel, I'le bite you by the tail.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: (Within) Miranda! Dorinda! Daughters, Daughters!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Oh I'me glad my Father comes, for when Fire and Flax are together, none knows how soon mischief may be done. Dorinda, Dorinda, my Fathers coming.

div.stage: Enter Dorinda and Hypolito hastily. Hypolito runs off.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O Sister pray lets Dance our new Heroick Song that our Father mayn't know who was here.
sp.stage: They Sing and Dance. Enter Prospero observing them.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Here comes a lusty Wooer, my dildin, my darling.
Here comes a lusty Wooer Lady bright and shining.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I Wooe for one of your fair Daughters, my dildin, my darling.
I Wooe for &c.— Lady bright &c.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I'm glad I have one for you my dild, &c.
I'm glad &c.— Lady bright, &c.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: She looks too brown upon me my dild, &c.
She looks &c.— Lady &c.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Enough, enough, all this won't blind me, come, come, come stand, stand you here, and you there, nay, nay, nay, no 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Indeed, and indeed, pray Father, I did but keep the door.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Didst thou keep the door for thy younger Sister?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, pray Father, that I did.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Blessing on thy pretty heart, cherish that gentile Motherly humour, thou hast a generous Soul; and since I see thy mind so apt to take the light impression of a modish Love, I will unfold a secret to thee— That Creature▪ that thou saw'st, is a kind of a Creature which is much like another Creature, that shall be nameless, and that's Quakero.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: But Father, pray Father, shall that Quakero Creature be my Husband? You said I should have a Husband before she, that you did.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Shortly my Miranda thou shalt see the flower of this bud; this Chit, chit, chit, chit, Cock-sparrow husband may serve thy Sister well enough, thou shalt have a ho-ho-ho-ho-Husband, a Horseman, goin I'le provide for thee.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Let me have the ho-ho, quickly then pray Father.
Father, Father, I forgot to make my Cursy; b'wy Father.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Come hither Dorinda, why saw you this Husband without my order?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Who I! truely I didn't saw'd him 'twas he saw'd me.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Come, come, your Sister told me all.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Then she fibs for ought I know, for she would ha' seen him first, if I would ha' let her.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Tell me what past between you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nothing pass'd between us but our great dog Towzer.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: What did he do t'ee? come confess.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: He did nothing, but I am affraid he wou'd if you hadn't come.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Why, why speak out?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Because he came towards me with his tail up as stiffe as any thing.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Ha, I thought as much; wha what did he do then? the truth, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why he did nothing but walk to his Kennel.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Walk'd to his Kennel— who?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why our great dog Towzer.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Pho, thou understandst me not, what did the Husband-thing do to thee?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why nothing at all, for just as we got to the Parsly-bed, you frighten'd it away.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: I charge you see it no more, 'twill Poyson you, and make you swell as big as a house.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Not see it, I'le run th'rough Nine Walls, but I'le see it, and have it to, though it make me swell 'till I break in peeces.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Go get you in, y'are a naughty Girle.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: The World's come to a very fine pass for ought I know, one can't play with a thing an hour or two alone, or be in bed with a man, but one must be naught: I won't endure it much long, that I wont so. Exit Dorinda.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: So— my wishing Pipe
Has swell'd my hopeing Cistern to a Flood.
Dorind ' and Polito's agreed, that's good.
Now for Miranda, and the youth Quakero;
When they are coupl'd too— there ends my Care'o.

div.head: Act IV. Scene III.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.p: MY hands are so tyr'd with stareing about for meat, that my feet can look no further— I must rest my old bones.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Old Lord I cannot blame thee, for I am seiz'd with such a griping, that I cannot rest.— My Courtyers us'd to tell me I had no humane imperfection; But here I will put off my hose and keep it no longer for my Flatterers Musick as in Air.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.p: Ha, these are a sort of doggish greedy Devils, come to devour the meat e'r 'tis dish'd up.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Do not for one repulse forgo the great design you were about to act.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.p: Oh help, help, something unseen has ty'd my hands behind me.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Mine are stollen away too, and 'tis well for 'em, for my mouth is grown so angry for want of meat, that if they should again appear empty it would devour them.

sp.speaker: Anto.
